Name: N,N-Dimethyl-alpha-methylcarbamoyloxyimino-alpha-(methylthio)acetamide
Description: Oxamyl is a carbamate ester. It has a role as an EC 3.1.1.7 (acetylcholinesterase) inhibitor, a carbamate insecticide, an acaricide, an antinematodal drug and an agrochemical. It is functionally related to a methylcarbamic acid.

plant_translocations.content: Tomato plants were treated with 20 kg/Feddan of 10% granules of either oxamyl or carbofuran. The results showed that both compounds were transferred from the roots of tomato plants to their fruits. The concentration of oxamyl in tomato fruits reached 33.4 ppb after one day of application, increased to 123.5 ppb after 10 days, and then decreased to 51.1 ppb at the end of the 21-day experiment. On the other hand, the absorbed amount of carbofuran in tomato fruits reached 312.9 ppb after one day, increased to 1003 ppb after 10 days, and then declined to 130.1 ppb at the end of the experiment. The average recoveries of oxamyl and carbofuran from tomato fruits at various spiking levels were 82.6% and 80.2%, respectively. Oxamyl was metabolized to oximino oxamyl, with the amount of this metabolite reaching 569.5 ppb after one day, increasing to 609.9 ppb after three days, and then dropping to 184.8 ppb after 10 days before increasing again to 300.1 ppb at the end of the experiment. On the other hand, carbofuran was slightly metabolized to 3-hydroxycarbofuran and 3-ketocarbofuran phenol, with the levels of 3-hydroxycarbofuran being greater than 3-ketocarbofuran phenol at all times following application. The results indicated that the translocation and persistence of carbofuran were greater than oxamyl in tomato plants.
plant_translocations.reference: Salama, Ahmed (1998). Translocation and metabolism of oxamyl and carbofuran in tomato plants grown in greenhouses. Journal of Environmental Science and Health, Part B, 33(5), 569–579.doi:10.1080/03601239809373163

method.Plant Grown Condition: Tomato plants, Lycopersicon esculantum Mill, were grown in rows in green house located in the experimental farm of the College of Agrie. & Vet. Med., KSA where the temperature was maintained at 25 ± 2 °C.
method.Chemical Preparation: Oxamyl [N,N-dimethyl-2-methyl carbamoyl oxyimino-2-(methylthio) acetamide] or carbofuran [2,3-dihydro-2,2-dimethyl benzofuranyl-N-methyl carbamate] formulation at the rate of 20 kg/Feddan of the granules (10% G)
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: Treated samples, two fruits from each replicate, were collected for residue analysis at 1, 3, 7, 10, 15, and 21 days after pesticide application.

plant_translocations.content: The study investigated the movement of the nematicide oxamyl from the foliage to the root and into the rhizosphere using pot experiments and bioassays. The results demonstrated basipetal translocation, as shown by the decrease in root galling and virus transmission caused by Longidorus elongatus. Analysis of tissues from potato plants treated with foliar applications of [14C]oxamyl indicated that only a small amount of the nematicide was translocated symplastically. Bioassays using Turbatrix aceti and Xiphinema diversicaudatum suggested that exudates from cucumber plants treated with foliar oxamyl were nematicidal, although the results varied widely. Gas-liquid chromatography analysis of the exudate showed very small amounts of the nematicide. The study concluded that basipetal translocation of oxamyl following foliar applications could provide some protection against nematodes at the root surface and possibly in the immediate rhizosphere. However, the amount of nematicidal exudate produced was unlikely to provide adequate control of nematodes in the soil mass at any distance from the plants.
plant_translocations.reference: Bromilow, R.H.; Alphey, T.J.W.; Abdalla, A.M.  (1985). Phloem Translocation of Foliar-Applied Oxamyl and Its Role in Plant Protection. Nematologica, 31(4), 468–477.doi:10.1163/187529285x00562

method.Plant Grown Condition: Single seedlings were planted in small pots (25-ml) containing a sterile sand/soil mixture. Each pot was planted with samples of Longidorus elongatus, a nematode that carries raspberry ringspot virus, added in 4 ml of water. The pots were then maintained in a temperature-controlled box at 17-19°C with 18 hours of supplementary light per day as necessary.
method.Chemical Preparation: Oxamyl [N,N-dimethyl-2-methyl carbamoyl oxyimino-2-(methylthio) acetamide] and carbofuran [2,3-dihydro-2,2-dimethyl benzofuranyl-N-methyl carbamate]
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: [14C]oxamyl was applied to the terminal leaves of tomato plants at a temperature range of 18-22°C under natural summer daylight conditions. The application was done by spreading the [14C]oxamyl over each leaflet using 100 µl of distilled water per leaflet, applied as approximately 80 drops from a microsyringe. The application rate was 107 µg and 0.1 µCi per plant. Subsequently, water was applied directly to the soil.

plant_translocations.content: The uptake of four 14C-labelled non-ionised compounds, including the insecticide/nematicide oxamyl and three model phenylureas, from solution by rooted stems of the aquatic plant parrot feather [Myriophyllum aquaticum (Vell.) Verdc], along with translocation to emergent shoots, was measured over 24 and 48 hours. Uptake into submerged tissues of roots and stem base involved two processes: movement into the aqueous phase of cells and then partitioning onto the plant solids. This partitioning process was influenced by lipophilicity (measured by the l-octanol/water partition coefficient, Kow), resulting in higher uptake rates of more lipophilic compounds. Translocation to shoots was passive and most efficient at a log Kow of about 1.8, where the efficiency was about 40% of that of water. This optimal log Kow was similar to that observed in barley, although the translocation efficiency was slightly lower in parrot feather. Solvation parameters were used to model uptake and translocation of a set of ten compounds by barley, aiming to understand why translocation efficiency is reduced at log Kow > 1.8.
plant_translocations.reference: De Carvalho, R. F., Bromilow, R. H., & Greenwood, R. (2007). Uptake and translocation of non‐ionised pesticides in the emergent aquatic plant parrot feather Myriophyllum aquaticum. Pest Management Science: formerly Pesticide Science, 63(8), 798-802.

method.Plant Grown Condition: Darkened glass crystallizing dish, 22±2°C, natural light, 12cm long rooted cuttings, 3 plants per vessel, 8g total weight per vessel
method.Chemical Preparation: Four 14C-labelled compounds: three analogues of phenylurea herbicides and the insecticide/nematicide oxamyl, specific activities of about 9 MBq/mmol, radiochemical purity > 98%
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: 5 µM aqueous solution of each compound, 100 mL per vessel, 24 and 48 hour uptake periods
method.Other Information: Two replicate vessels, three plants per vessel, samples stored at -15°C if required prior to analysis, aliquots (2×1.0 mL) of the root-bathing solution taken initially and at the end of the exposure periods for analysis.
